Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Diversity and Disease in a Post-Trauma Urban Landscape

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will focus on ecological and socioeconomic processes following the catastrophic flooding in New Orleans associated with Hurricane Katrina in August 2005. Urban landscapes are excellent settings within which to examine interactions ecological and human communities. Urban areas that have experienced a traumatic event can be highly tractable systems for studying potential parallels between ecological and socioeconomic systems as well as feedbacks among them. With acute trauma resulting in an initial state change, the assembly and reassembly of proximate or coincident urban ecological and human communities can be a coupled dynamic, where outcomes are contingent on responses to common forcing factors or interactions arising from management interventions. The catastrophic flooding of New Orleans following Hurricane Katrina resulted in a natural laboratory for investigating assembly and reassembly of coupled natural and human systems. The investigators will determine the extent to which ecological and socioeconomic diversity exhibited parallel responses to Katrina-related flooding. They also will examine how interventions executed as public health measures shaped relationships and interactions between ecological and socioeconomic diversity. They will conduct geographic information system-based analyses of landscape heterogeneity and socioeconomic variation before and after Hurricane Katrina as well as plot-based inventories of post-Katrina plant communities while accounting for flooding and socioeconomic stratification. They will examine the ecology and demography of Norway rats (Rattus norvegicus), a habitat-dependent primary reservoir of zoonotic pathogens, in order to understand human health outcomes of flooding. This facet of the research will involve a trap-based census; population genetic analysis of abundance and dispersal, and histological analysis of pathogen prevalence. Mail surveys and in-person interviews of households proximate to plant inventory and trapping sites as well as households in four neighborhoods having different income and ethnicity characteristics will be administered to determine how perceptions of risk compare to physical measures of exposure risk across the city. Information gained from these studies will be integrated into a spatially explicit predictive model of Norway rat demography to assess ecological and human-health outcomes of alternative control scenarios reflecting habitat suitability, movement, and risk perceptions.

Trauma can have enduring consequences on environments and societies. Understanding the interplay between ecological and human communities will better prepare societies to anticipate and manage trauma inflicted by catastrophic events. This project will help catalyze conceptual unification of disparate fields of research on the composition, assembly, and structure of communities, and it will generate new information and insights needed to foster and inform societal action at a time when unprecedented resources are being invested to rebuild New Orleans. By involving community partners, cross-university academic and public outreach programs will provide opportunities to promote awareness of trauma, diversity, and public health across stakeholder and underrepresented groups in the city. With urbanization placing an increasingly greater proportion of the global population at risk because of catastrophic events, lessons about the traumas experienced by New Orleans will provide new knowledge of scholarly and practical value to residents and decision makers in communities around the world. This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This interdisciplinary research project examined the social-ecological recovery of New Orleans following catastrophic flooding associated with Hurricane Katrina in August 2005. The project characterized socioeconomic rehabilitation and ecological reassembly across the city, focusing on public health concerns that have been shaped by public policies governing resettlement, rebuilding, and land management. This involved GIS-based assessment of land use and sociodemographic variation before and after Hurricane Katrina, as well as plot-based inventories of urban tree and understory plant communities according to flooding and sociodemographic stratification. It also involved examining the ecology and demography of Norway rats (Rattus norvegicus) and Roof rats (Rattus rattus), which are both habitat-dependent reservoirs of zoonotic pathogens of human concern. Trap-based censuses were completed across neighborhoods factorially selected according to income and flooding history, complemented by population genomic studies of abundance, distribution, and dispersal. This work was paired with molecular and histological analysis of endoparasitic, bacterial and viral infections of trapped rodents. Mail surveys of households at trapping sites were conducted to determine how perceptions of risk compare to physical measures of exposure risk across the city. Information gained from these studies was used to parameterize predictive models of rat demography to assess outcomes of alternative control scenarios reflecting habitat suitability, movement, and risk perceptions.

In the decade since Hurricane Katrina, New Orleans has regained ≥80% of its pre-storm population, with many neighborhoods at ≥100% pre-Katrina residency, but the extent of recovery and associated economic and environmental benefits are not uniformly distributed among social groups or neighborhoods. Comparisons of land cover showed that Katrina-related flooding reduced landscape diversity across the city, but plot-based plant surveys demonstrated that ecological differences among neighborhoods align with measures of disaster response as much or more so than flooding disturbance. Institutional programs intended to foster population return and recovery have instead resulted in striking mosaics of abandonment that have reinforced legacies of sociodemographic disparities. Commensal rats were found to be far more abundant and in better condition in flood-affected areas burdened with more abandonment, substantiated by greater prevalence of vacant lots, debris, and unmaintained vegetation. Likewise, greater rodent abundance and richness also occurred in areas burdened with more abandonment and infrastructure loss. Though pathogen distributions were heterogeneous across the city, evidence was found that rodent host diversity amplified the prevalence- and thus transmission risk- of particular pathogens of concern, such as Leptospira bacteria. Notably, disease risk perceptions reflected physical measures of disease risk, such as rat abundance, especially in neighborhoods where residents are more likely to encounter a pathogen host.

Findings from this research illustrate that catastrophic disasters can leave indelible social-ecological signatures in affected areas, and highlight how discriminatory and neglectful public policies can coalesce to fortify sociocultural disparities by elevating rather than alleviating potential risks to human well-being (i.e., following Katrina, historically underserved communities became burdened with abandoned properties harboring rodents that can carry pathogens of human concern). Viewing abandonment and associated disease risk through the lens of environmental justice highlights how reducing 'green blight' could prevent or disrupt negative feedback cycles (i.e., between landscape aesthetics, social stigmas, redevelopment, and public policy) in disaster-affected neighborhoods that might otherwise become bound in a downward spiral of declining capital investment, land abandonment, and population loss. Taking proactive steps to manage abandoned areas can potentially mitigate public health concerns in disaster-affected areas. Findings from this study point to the prospects that interventions such as vegetation management, removal of blighted buildings, and debris removal can be executed to address disparities.  Likewise, careful consideration of social-ecological outcomes of disaster-driven disturbance, (re)settlement and land use can help improve disaster planning and recovery. Evidence that abandonment is disproportionately concentrated in areas of lower income in cities across the US suggests that the conditions found in post-Katrina New Orleans likely occur across a broad geography. And given the near global distribution of the three most commonly encountered rodent species, lessons learned from post-Katrina New Orleans are likely to be broadly applicable and of increasing importance as trends in coastal urbanization and tropical storm intensity are placing an increasingly greater proportion of the global population at risk of experiencing a catastrophic disaster.
